transcript.content: So welcome to episode three of this final Ricky Gervais show series with me, Ricky Gervais, Stephen Merchant.
Hello.
And Carl Pilkington.
All right.

Have you heard this thing they're doing? The schools have got together. They're. They're tired of obesity being a problem in England. It's a big problem in England. Basically, everyone's overweight, particularly kids. There's kids that are like, you know, 10 stone going to infant school and stuff and junior school. It's getting ridiculous. And so now the teachers are allowed to weigh the kids. They're going to weigh the kids. Okay. Yeah. Get them in there and go, right, right, get on the scale. And then they're going to send a letter to the parents saying, please be aware your child is obese. Now, I don't know what good that's going to do because a teacher will send a letter to a parent, go, dear Mr. And Mrs. Barnes, we weighed little Johnny today at school and he's overweight. He's a big fat pig. And they're gonna go, yeah, we know we have to push him out the door to get him to school. He makes a popping sound. We know he's fat. He eats too much. We know he's fat because we have to buy him pairs of trousers every two weeks.
Yeah, well, we know he's fat because we're a couple of fat bastards.
Always. I love that when they say about our child obese. They show you a picture of a kid and is nearly closed up.
Yeah.

It's just closed. Right. There's no eyes anymore. He's got little slits for eyes where his cheeks and his forehead are meeting. Yeah. And you know what I mean? And then you see the parents, they go, wow. Yeah. We can't do anything. And you go, no, look at you.
Yeah. No, I saw a couple the other day. I saw a dad, giant arse.
Yeah.
And then I was walking behind them and two kids, exactly the same. Giant arses.
Yeah.
Now that.
I don't. I can't believe that that's.
Well, they eat the same things. You can't.
Like a couple of bison.
Yeah. If they're. If they're. Yeah. If the parents are just e. They can't save the kids. You've had enough. They're going, what the fuck?
Look at you. I saw him in the. In Tesco supermarket. You know, they've got, like, cafes in.
There now, have they?
Big fat family in there. The fact that they're buying food and they're having a break from buying food to eat food yeah, Just sums up.

It may have been peckish, didn't it? I mean that, don't forget, that is the only exercise they get pushing a trolley round. They get home and then they wedge themselves in that three piece suite and they're watching ITV1 for the rest of the night.
Yeah.
And. And eating cakes and things. Microwavable stuff.
Well, they're actually. They're watching X Factor, but they're not. They're only watching X Factor. Waiting for the adverts for Pringles.
Exactly.
Pizza.
Exactly.
That's what they're looking forward to.
They could do that. They could make it a bit harder to shop, couldn't they? If you walk through a door, it.
Goes ding, ding, ding.
And. And you go, go. And for fat people, the shopping moves around a bit.
Moving away, it's.
Yeah, exactly. You're putting it on a string.
Y.
You want the pie and they have to at least get up a bit of a sweat.
Well, they're on the conveyor belts like in a sushi restaurant. They just gotta chase after the oven. Fried chips.
Unbelievable.
Or is there some kind of cattle grid device that only fat. Is there anything that we could put.
Oh, you can only get to this. Get to the thing if you can get through this. Right, yeah, that's a good point. Yeah. So the really fattening stuff is through a thin door or just.
Yeah, or one of those kind of those sort of tubes that soldiers, you see, have to crawl through when they're doing their training.
And that's to pies. Yeah. The shop is full of salads. You can go around, you can even eat as you go around.
It's like a forest of salads.
Exactly. You can graze and you can buy. But if you want to get to the pies and cakes and all that, you've got to get through a little tube.
Crawl through a little tube.
Yeah. It would just be forever going, dude, fat bloke stuck in aisle three. They'd have to keep getting them out.

Well, I was stuck behind one on the tube. It got out of the tube on the escalators and you know, like on escalators you're meant to stand to the right so people can get past. Yeah. Waste of time in standing on the right.
Yeah.

Taking up the full thing. He had a tracksuit on, like they always do, you know. Never seen a track in its life, that tracksuit. And so I stayed behind him because he had no option. He saw everyone behind me sort of going, what's the old up here? Like a convoy of People going, what's up the front? What's happening here? What's up? And he's saying, sort of blocking it. He gets to the bit, you know, where you have to put your ticket in or your Oyster card and swipe it. He had to go through the bit for trolleys.
How embarrassing is that?
Unbelievable.
But that's when you know, innit? That's when you go, you know what?

Exactly. But I don't. There's enough stigma, I think, because, you know, political correctness now and. And, you know, and the fact that food is so refined, there's no stigma anymore. I laugh about being fat. I should be ashamed. I should walk down the street, go, fatty. That's. That's what I want to get me out of there. I. I get up in the morning, I look in the mirror, I go, are you fat bastard? Yeah, but no, I think.
I think the same every time I see you.
I know, but look how successful I am. But you're right, you know, there should be.
You know, people look up to you, Rick. That's a problem. You're a role model. They've got pictures of you on their wall. I often get stuck in their face.

A role model for. People want to be. Now, maybe they don't mean they want to make a successful sitcom and be rich and famous. Maybe they mean, I want to eat as much as I want and no one say anything about it.
The number of times I've seen you on one of those. The ideal dinner guest. You're not the ideal dinner guest. Well, firstly, there'd be nothing else to go around for anyone else.
And I'm always early.
Right.
So by the time anyone. That'd be it. Yeah. Yeah. The ideal. As long as he comes halfway through the meal.
And I think they mean, oh, it'd be funny because he'd be very witty and charming. No, he'd just be stuffing his face for two hours.
Wouldn't be talking. If there's food there, I'll just listen. I can listen. I mean, I can't really hear because when I chow down, some of it gets in my ears.
Sure, Yeah.
I will go deep into a pasta.
Yeah. The face is in the bowl.
I'm actually deaf and blind for four minutes that I'm eating. It's like when a horse bolts.
Yeah.
They can't see or hear anything. They just bolt. But, you know, I don't know what we could do, really. I mean.
I mean, I think we should be clear here. We're not. We're not saying, you know, we don't want to encourage.
We're not saying fat people are all right. We're saying they're wrong.
Well, yeah, but I want to make. No, I want to make an important point here, which is that we're not talking. Well, we're not talking about how. Listen.
What.

This is an important point. There's a lot of young people, you know, and they. They don't eat and stuff because they want to try and look like Victoria Beckham, all that stuff. Oh, we're not talking about that. We're not talking about just being, you know, respectable size, a little bit curvy, whatever. You don't got to be like a size zero. We're not talking about that debate.
Definitely not.
We're talking about the crazy obesity that's going on. Five foot two, you're weighing 14 stone. Absolutely. It's a time to probably stop going to the all you can eat buffet.
Yeah.
Which is not a competition, incidentally.
But, you know, it's because you'd.
Like you said, though, you're not allowed to call Fatty anymore. Like when I ask, when I was at school if he was a fat kid.
Yeah.
He did get, you know, sort of being picked on. On. That isn't good.
His nickname was Pie or Fatty, but.
He'D sort of be chased to be beaten up, so at least he got a run. Now, kids aren't allowed to pick on little fat kids.
No, I know.
So it's not running anywhere. And it gets worse.
See that? Maybe that's it. Is that. Is that a good thing? If you pick on a fat kid and steal his lunch money, Is that being. Is that cruel to be kind? Do you know what I mean?
Survival of the fittest again, isn't it?

But I mean, you know, they go. They go, okay, Jobson, you picked on little Fatty again and nicked his lunch money. You go, yeah, I thought he was eating too much and I'm worried about his heart. And I go, oh, well done, Jobson.
Yeah, go pick up some more fat.
People, nick all their lunch.
I don't know what the rules are. I mean, it's all gone crazy.
I mean, I think I'm allowed to call people fat because I am a bit fat.
You're reclaiming the word.
It's like black people can say the N word. I can say the F word. I can say. I can say fatty because I am fat.

You know, it is remarkable. I mean, you've seen pictures of Ricky, Shorty, Carl in his youth. I mean, you know, a kind of David Bowie like facing a very different person. But anyone who's ever seen that to me has said, I don't understand. They're just genuinely baffled. I mean it is weird. It's really. I don't understand, Rick, how you've gone from that. People should look you up on the web and it doesn't make any sense.
Don't Jane get annoyed? Don't you feel like she's been ripped off?
No. When I was 20, I was 20 and then, and I stayed like that till I was about 29 and then, then I thought, oh, well then I started feeling out. Then I was sort of like when.
You'Re about 36 and you were.
Yeah. Oh, I was already there. No, I'd done the eating years then, boy. No, I went from about, I mean in those pictures I was probably like eight and a half stone too thin.
Yeah.
And then I was like nine and then 30, 31 went to 10 stone and then about a stone a year. I think I was my fattest when just after.
Yeah.
So yeah, I'm, I'm like 14 stone now.
But it's like, it's like if you look at it on the web or something, compare the two, it's like one of those Weight Watchers before and after, but the wrong way around. Yeah, it's really strange.

Yeah. So. So I feel that I can have a go at fat people. I think I can claim the word I can call fatty. Like Steve can have a go at, like you can have a go at bald people. Carl, you can go, look at that round headed bald twat. You will never see someone as round headed and bald as you.
But.
And Steve can go, oh look Rick, look at that fucking twatish goggle eyed freak over there. No, no, no.
How often would that happen?
Hang on, let's slag Ricky off a bit more, can we? And Fatos.
Also I've got. This is how much I've let go. Steve, it's finally happened. I want you to test my trousers. There, feel them.
Oh, what is that? That is some pajamas. Are you actually wearing pajamas?
I'm actually wearing. It happened today. That's the first time.
Now, was it because of speed you had to get out of the house?

No. I'll tell you why. Okay. The last couple years, I mean for the last, I'd say 10 years, I've been wearing comfortable clothes. I never wear a pair of jeans that too tight. I don't wear shoes that. It's just comfort for me. I mean you, you see me fidget when I put A suit on for an award ceremony.
Yeah.

I don't like it. Okay. I never look good in stuff. You see it on the model in the. In the shop window. Puts it on you. Oh, well, okay. So that's great. They look like David Beckham. I put it on. I look like a wallet or something.
Just.
It doesn't look good. I've been wearing as, you know, sweatpants. Right. You know, a drawstring. Yeah.
Okay.
I got a pair of sweatpants recently that are nearly pajamas.
They're so, I mean, what is the distinction at this point?
I don't. I don't know.
It's quite a thin line.
So they're nearly pyjamas today. They're in the wash. So I thought, hold on, though. I might as well just wear my pyjamas.

I should point out that it's not a 1950s pair of pyjamas. That looks a bit like a suit with a little breast pocket. No, you wouldn't necessarily notice until you touch them. You realize there's a kind of lycra.

Yeah, they're very sort of nice and thin. They look like a tracksuit bottom. But here's the difference. I've even done away with a drawstring look. These are just elasticated. This is the day I really gave up. I used to worry about what I look like, obviously, when there was a, you know, when there was a nice sort of clothes. Horse to hang nice clothes on, ie my body, you know, I. I did squeeze into jeans. I did, you know, where I was, I was. I was fashionable. But did you.
I can't imagine you going in shops, though, and looking through racks of clothes and did you do all that stuff, Steve?

I look good in anything, mate. That's the. That's the difference now. Doesn't matter. Armani could dress me. Doesn't matter. Yeah, he's not. Not that he'd want to. I can't believe I keep getting offered from people like him. And designers call my agent saying, does he want us to dress him for the. The Emmys do pyjamas. Well, exactly one, I think. Why do they wonder, what is that going to put sales up? Is someone going to be watching that and go, yeah, that bloke looks short and fat and sweaty. Get me Armani on the phone.
Maybe that's someone from the Emmy committee going, can you phone up Ricky Gervais and just check that when they say, can we dress him from the Emmys, we mean, can we make sure he's dressed?

Yeah, can we Tuck him in and leave his slippers at the hotel. But, yeah, so I don't do it anyway because I'm mildly embarrassed. We went around those sort of luxury lounges where they give you things. They give you these, like suits. Like Armani, Hugo Boss. They're just giving you suits.
I heard about this.
Oh, yeah?
When's this going on?
Yeah, when? Before, like the Emmys. Every. Every what?
A. I was out there, but no one notified me.
Maybe you didn't get an invite.
What do you mean I didn't get an invite?
Yeah, yeah. The first one I went to, I was mildly embarrassed, man. Then I saw like, Helen Mirren, the Sopranos.
Bloody Helen Mirren's going around there and I'm not. Yeah, yeah, but she's got more money than me. She doesn't need to go and get free stuff.
She's the queen. She's the richest woman in the world.
Fucking hell.

Yeah, you've missed out, Steve. And they measure you and everything. I've taken. I've taken one suit. I've taken one suit and I think a jacket. But usually what I do is I say I have a pair of sunglasses. I'm like Alton John at home. I've got a drawer full of the best sunglasses in the world. One off editions of these beautiful sunglasses where I'm embarrassed not to take something. They're incredible. They just give you all these things, you know?
I feel like the kid in the Pied Piper. Remember when the Pied Piper, as revenge, he takes all the kids to a sort of magical land inside a rock where there's just sweets and fun.
But the little lame boy, he can't get in there.
He's left behind in the rat. Formerly rat infested town.
But he had the last laugh, didn't he? Because he could go and get locked in the cave.
Yeah, but he didn't. They weren't locked. It was a magical land inside the cave. He wanted to be in there.
Was it?
Yes, obviously.
Or was he a paedophile?
That's gotta be. That's gotta be better than being stuck in a town with rats and old people. At least he gets sweets and a puppy.
I worried. Then for a minute I thought, oh, that's libelous.
What?
The Pied Piper was a pedophile. Excuse me. It's the Pied Piper. Here we are.
We represent the Pied Piper.

We represent the Pied Fiddler. The Pied Piper. Yeah. I mean, I. You know, I used to. I used to care about fashion, but I also had little mistakes if you're being creative with clothing, not everything's a winner.
Yeah.
Do you know what I mean? You can't always look good.
Even.
Even when I thought I looked good in everything.
So what was just quickly, what sort of era are we talking?
Well, obviously, student. That's when I sort of did the.
And what was your default look?

Neuromantic. I mean, you know, first thing I did when I got to college, dyed my hair. Blousy shirts, blouse shirts. But I dyed it black. Sometimes military. Military was very big then, so, you know, you'd have dyed black hair and a bit of eyeliner, but, you know, maybe look a bit. A bit sort of, you know, gorilla. Then I got signed when I was in a pop band, a failed pop band very quickly, but, you know, I bought designer clothes. But then it all went okay. So the poor years from when I was about, I don't know, 22 to 29, before I got a job, four years starting.
22. You had the high life by then.
Yeah.

And so we lived in that awful little place where I talk about it live where, you know, there was no toilet. So often I'd. I'd wee in the sink and so. So I thought, well, I didn't have any money at all. And I used to wear tracksuit all the time then.
Because I used.

To be fair, I used to run round London. I was on the dole. We had 16 quid between us a week to spend, right? So there was a lot of chili con carne being eaten and rice just filling up on rice and. And. And I'd run everywhere and I was like, run everywhere? Yeah, I just run. I'd get up and I'd run places. I'd run around the park. I'd run to visit friends who had jobs, I'd run to art galleries and I'd run London. That was. That was like my job.
Why were you running it? It sounds like it's the life of a smack head. I was running everywhere.

I was super fit in my 20s. I'm not only sort of like thin, but fit as well. I'd run at least 5 to 10 miles a day and work out. I do. I did karate twice a week. I'd. So I just. I mean, honestly, anything but a job. Anything but a job, yeah. Because I was trying to be a pop star and I told myself, no, I'm an artist, I can't possibly get a job. It's bohemian. I just eat rice. Well, I was fine. It was absolutely fine. Never. But I never thought, oh, this Is really annoying. I gotta get a job. I thought, you know, I haven't got a job. I'm doing this. I was signing on.
Were you?

Well, I couldn't. I couldn't because I hadn't had a job before that. So I think we got our rent paid, and then we'd split Jane's money that she earned. We got a rent paid and, you know, we were left with. I remember it being. It was 16 quid a week. And it was. It was the early 80s, mid-80s. So I didn't get new clothes, so I had some, you know, old ones and, you know, go to jumble sales. It's fine. Okay. But I remember once we were getting new curtains, and the old ones that were in this flat were like sort of a chintzy, sort of goldish sort of line with a thread in them with sort of leafy pattern, very sort of thick.
What kind of late 70s style?
Yeah, exactly. And Jane was gonna took the old ones down. I went, don't throw them away. I'll make a suit out of those.
Yeah, of course.
So sort of Jane just sort of nodded and went, okay. And she went to work. So I thought, wow, okay, let's have a go. I've never made a suit before, but how hard can it be? Yeah, I mean, I used to.
That would be my first thought.

I used to make everything I used to make, I remember, made shelves once. I found three bits of wood in a skip, okay. And I sort of put two vertically and put one across the top, Right. So it was like, you know, a goal post.
Right.

I thought I put a nail in each side. It sort of wobbled. I put it against the wall and it wouldn't stand up. It sort of, like, leaned, like. I made a parallelogram. So what I did, I put another nail in it and I tied a bit of string to it and pulled the string tight. I pulled it across the room and put another nail in the window sill. And so now there's this shelf that wants to fall over but can't because it's tied to another wall. So that was.
So you spent Most of this, the 80s, running around London and collecting debris and making your home outfit. You sound like a womble.
Yeah, but I wasn't shaped like one until I was 32.
And, you know, this is kind of. You were making everything except a living.
Yeah, exactly.
Right.

So. So I thought, right, how do I make a suit? I thought, well, I used to go to the library and learn. I don't know. I can Make a suit. You know, I don't want to do it like other people. I'll do it differently. So. So my method for making this made to measure suit was I got one of the sets of curtains and laid them on the floor.
Right.
I laid down on the curtain and drew around my legs.
Okay, hang on. So you were making the trousers first?

Yeah. So I thought, hold on, that's just one side of the trouser. So I laid down another curtain and drew my legs again. And I thought, well, I'll cut those out. So now I've cut out two leg shaped curtain pieces, right. I put them together, sewed them up. Of course it was nowhere big enough, of course, because I'd left no room, right?
Yeah.

So I tried to squeeze into them. I mean, they look like jodhpur's, they look like tights. Okay. So I thought, ah, this is really hard. Right. I pulled them off again, right. I thought, how am I gonna make the jacket? I didn't. I just used one of the curtains as a cape. So I thought, I mean, I look like a gay Hamlet. I mean, it's ridiculous, right? So what I did was.
Did you squeeze into the trousers you wore?
The trousers I sort of squeezed. I couldn't wear them though. So what I did was I rolled it up and shoved it under the chair.
You rolled up what?

Sorry, the suit I made. Jane came in about a few days later. It was that I said, that's where I had a go at the suit. And she pulled it out and, you know, died laughing. The idea that this man sat down and drew around his legs to make some trousers.
Well, firstly, why did you not just straight away, why did you stash it under the.
I don't know.

Because I thought you were watching TV on the sofa and she was a foot higher than you thought, what's going on here? And there was a suit stuffed. I mean, why not just throw it away? I don't understand.
I don't know. That's what you do, isn't it? You think, oh, maybe again.
We were talking before about the fact that you used to be very thin and now you're very fat. And this seems like two different people.
Very fat.
Well, most people would say you are, but wearing black. It seems as though you were also an idiot when you were younger. I mean like a. Because you're a smart man now. I don't.
Well, I know.
Why would it not occur to you that you couldn't make your own decision?

Because I've always thought I could do anything I've always thought I could make a suit. Of course I can make a suit. I'll be brilliant at that. I'll make a suit. And it took me. It took me getting fat to realize the world doesn't lay down to you.
Yeah.
I thought, well, I'll never be fat. I will never be fat. Look at me. Look at me, you know.
So I suppose even as you were getting fat, that must be the mirror, James. Problem with the mirror?

No. At least I can put eyes on. On myself. As soon as I started getting fat, I started saying I was fat before I was fat. Because when you've been really thin, you know, I mean, I couldn't get anywhere near those curtains now. Oh, I couldn't. They wouldn't go past me ankle now.
Kept them.
Yeah, they're under the chair.
Yeah, yeah, you. And you said, of course, if someone comes to the door and you can't be bothered to reach for your pajamas, maybe just wrap the curtain around you.
I just pop the curtain around me. Yeah. I could probably make a pair of pants out of them. I mean, soon I will be in nappies, is which would be easy to make, so. But when I'm older and Dan goes.
Just off to work. Where are those pillowcases?
Doesn't matter, doesn't matter. I need changing.
God. Food's too nice, though, innit? That's. That's where the. Where the problem is.
Well, yeah, some food.
Well, no, a lot. A lot of food. More food's nice. Now. I find that I eat because I go, that's nice. Rather than I'm hungry.
Oh, yeah. I stopped eating when I was hungry when I was about 29.
Yeah.
I used to go eat. Now I've got other stuff to do. We got to eat. Yeah, Shove it in. Right. And then that. I've never. I've never only ate because I was hungry for many, many years.

But it's not just that either, is it? Like, we've got mates who've had a kid now and that's eating stuff that. Seriously, I'm not. I'm not joking. That is having stuff that I've never had and it hasn't even got teeth yet. I mean, what sort of things are you talking about? Mango. I only have that. I had mango about a year and a half ago. And it's all right. I mean, it's not one of my favorite. Is it fruit? Yeah, but there's so much other fruit that's. That's better.
Go on. I think what's better than the mango the banana springs to mind. The strawberry just.
I like, I like the ones that you can just go, I'm nipping out. What can I take with me? I'll have an apple.
Well, the banana is the best because it's got its own little carry case.
Yeah, that's all right. But they're saying that, you see, this is why we've got more fat people in supermarkets now. You can buy cut up apple in a bag.
Really?
That's lazy in it. That is lazy.
Again, I've got to confess that I have my portions of fruit first thing in the morning liquidized.
Yeah.
I have a smoothie, I put all the fruit in there, I drink it, I'm not chewing. You want me to eat fruit, I'm not chewing it.
At the end of the day, food's nice.
Yeah.
There's loads of it.
Well, no, there is in the Western world. There is. Yeah. I'm saying there's not.
Yeah, but this is the whole point, isn't it, about the. The gluttonous west is that we are indulging ourselves.
Yeah.
If we were scrabbling around starving like a third world country, we wouldn't be in that situation. Well, there's only drinking the fizzy lemonade. Exactly.

There's loads of it. And now every time I buy something, it's a two for one. So you end up buying more than you need. And then Suzanne's always saying, eat this ham, will you? It's going off, I don't even want it.
Why is she buying so much ham?
Because it's two for one offer. We don't need two lots. But the person at the till goes, you know, this is two for one. You go, nip back and get one.
I know, yeah.

They never do half price. They do two for one. Exactly. They did that with a meal. Once we were in LA and we had a meal and they said, you know, it's happy hour, it's two for one. So I went, well, can we just have one each? We've got to give it to you. And they brought two meals for everyone. It was ridiculous.

I am tell you another problem that I've worked out. It might, might make a slight difference on fat people. Don't put a light in a fridge because that's just, that's just at night when they get peckish, they can see everything that's in there. Don't put the light there. You don't need a light in a fridge. There's no lights in other cupboards yet. Where this food is like Fat is getting up at 4 in the morning. What can I have? What's that at the back? Get rid of the light that. Eat less.
That might. There might be some logic in that.
That's interesting.
Well, what's it there for? Tell me what that light is there for. They say, turn off your standby light, yet you've got a light in your fridge showing you where tomatoes, you know.
But it's turned off when you shut. The light's not on when the door's not open.
Yes, but a fat person who's always got the fridge door open.

So what are you saying, in a way, is that the free market, capitalism being what it is, which has allowed companies, food manufacturers, to make them more full of more salt, more fat in order to attract you, in order to make more profits, it's actually resulting in obesity.
I was in a cafe, right? I normally like to go in there and I might have beans on toast, cheese cups. I might have a bit of cheese. Yeah.
Cheddar on top.
Only if the offer sometimes sort of thing, I shouldn't have it. So I'll only have it if they says, you want cheese.
Oh, okay.
And then it's down to their problem, you know, I mean, it's kind of like they made me have that.
Yeah.
So anyway, I'm sat in there, look.
How Ricky's glazed over, just thinking about cheese on toast.

Now I'm sat in there. This little fella, I'd say he was from like Africa or something, came in, he had a little top hat on, suitcase and red jeans. Dead happy, he was. I think he just turned up to London, it's his first day out and he's probably thinking, I can't, believe me, look at the choice here. Anyway, the difference was conjecture.
Yeah.

The difference was he went in and he said, have you got any porridge? He asked for two bowls for the price of one. There was a little bit of a. Like a fuffle. Yeah, a little bit. Because he couldn't understand why you've got loads of porridge. Give me two portions. But the what. What I found interesting is he didn't want to go for the doughnut or the pastry because in his country they don't. They don't have it.
